response.source_quote: In patients with diabetes, aspirin reduced MACE (RR 0.87, 95% CI 0.79-0.96) with increased bleeding risk.
Aspirin significantly reduced the risk of myocardial infarction (RR 0.82, 95% CI 0.71-0.94, p=0.006, I2=27%)
However, aspirin significantly increased the risk of major bleeding events (RR 1.47, 95% CI 1.31-1.65, I2=0%, number needed to harm NNH=210)

outcomes: OR for hypertension in Wuhan subgroup
OR for hypertension in non-Wuhan subgroup
OR for hypertension in younger patients

response.source_quote: Total patients: severe group 507, non-severe group 2,779.
Compared with non-severe patients, severe patients had a significantly higher prevalence of hypertension (pooled OR=2.98, 95% CI: 2.37-3.75, p<.001, I2=15.4%)
Compared with non-severe patients, severe patients had a significantly higher prevalence of diabetes (pooled OR=2.75, 95% CI: 2.09-3.62, p<.001, I2=26.1%).

Compared with non-severe patients, severe patients had a significantly higher prevalence of hypertension (pooled OR=2.98, 95% CI: 2.37-3.75, p<.001, I2=15.4%), diabetes (pooled OR=2.75, 95% CI: 2.09-3.62, p<.001, I2=26.1%), and cardiovascular disease (pooled OR=4.78, 95% CI: 2.71-8.42, p<.001, I2=52.5%).
Treatment group total in severity cohort: severe N=733, non-severe N=4,125. For the mortality cohort: non-survivors N=213, survivors N=946.
Hypertension was also associated with severe disease (OR=2.56, 95% CI: 1.82-3.59).
In the mortality analysis (6 studies, 1,159 patients), CVD was associated with significantly increased risk of death from COVID-19 (pooled OR=11.08, 95% CI: 2.59-47.32, p=0.001, I2=67%).
Treatment group total in severity cohort: severe N=733, non-severe N=4,125.
